pr_title: feat: Improve block placement of ceiling-supporting family

timeline.message:
Improve block placement of CeilingSupportingHorizontalFamily

Previously the only way to place blocks upside down, using the
CeilingSupportingHorizontalFamily, was to attach them to a BOTTOM
side. This commit makes it possible to achieve the same thing,
targeting horizontal sides.

Improve block placement of CeilingSupportingHorizontalFamily

Previously the only way to place blocks upside down, using the
CeilingSupportingHorizontalFamily, was to attach them to a BOTTOM
side. This commit makes it possible to achieve the same thing,
targeting horizontal sides.

timeline.body:
Instead of declaring `mainSide` and then mutating the value you could do the check first and just do a single-time assignment:

```suggestion
        final Side mainSide = upsideDownPlacement ? Side.BOTTOM : Side.TOP;
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
Instead of declaring mainSide and then mutating the value you could do the check first and just do a single-time assignment:

Suggested change
if (upsideDownPlacement) {
mainSide = Side.BOTTOM;
}
final Side mainSide = upsideDownPlacement ? Side.BOTTOM : Side.TOP;
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.bodyHTML:
Suggested change
Side mainSide = Side.TOP;
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.body: This assumes a cubic block, right? I'm totally fine with that, but maybe we should mention that in the doc comment?
timeline.bodyText: This assumes a cubic block, right? I'm totally fine with that, but maybe we should mention that in the doc comment?
timeline.bodyHTML: This assumes a cubic block, right? I'm totally fine with that, but maybe we should mention that in the doc comment?
timeline.author: skaldarnar

timeline.body: I'm wondering whether we have convenience for that in TeraMath....
timeline.bodyText: I'm wondering whether we have convenience for that in TeraMath....
timeline.bodyHTML: I'm wondering whether we have convenience for that in TeraMath....
timeline.author: skaldarnar

replies.bodyText:
I don't know, feels rather specific.
You mean a convenience for "testing if the absolute of a value is bigger than some value, considering some delta"?
There are no utility functions in TeraMath using the absolute functions, so I'm pretty sure it's not in there.
Also, I'm not sure how to name this, in case I wanted to move it to TeraMath. Any ideas?
replies.author: kBlaszczyk

replies.bodyText: Not necessarily with the Math.abs but the comparison of floating point numbers with some ε
replies.author: skaldarnar

timeline.body:
What about moving the null check into `getSideHitPosition`?

```suggestion
        Vector2f relativePlacementPosition = getSideHitPosition(event.getHitPosition(), targetPosition);
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
What about moving the null check into getSideHitPosition?

Suggested change
Vector2f relativePlacementPosition;
if (targetPosition != null) {
relativePlacementPosition = getSideHitPosition(event.getHitPosition(), targetPosition);
} else {
relativePlacementPosition = new Vector2f();
}
Vector2f relativePlacementPosition = getSideHitPosition(event.getHitPosition(), targetPosition);
timeline.author: skaldarnar

replies.bodyText:
I don't like this one.
My method wants a vector to work with, nobody should pass it null.
It is true however, that I'm cluttering up the higher level method, so I moved the null check into another private method, working on the event. I think it makes more sense that way and I hope you'll like that solution too.
replies.author: kBlaszczyk
